channel.title: Comments on: Haggadot 2010
channel.description: notes on Jewish theology and spirituality

item.title: By: Yonatan
item.dc:creator: Yonatan
item.description:
Regarding the Sacks shlit"a Haggadah, assuming that Sacks writes his own books, to what degree is his specific language that important?
Presumably he is processing his earlier sources and reformulating them in his own words.
Especially as he has been attacked for what he says and who he quotes, he is probably very careful about how he formulates his ideas.
Not to harp on a side point, but why not blaim the rabbanim for what is printed in their name? I could speculate about justifying their "Haggadot", but ultimately, they have a veto power about what is printed by Artscroll in their name.
item.content:encoded:
Regarding the Sacks shlit”a Haggadah, assuming that Sacks writes his own books, to what degree is his specific language that important?

Presumably he is processing his earlier sources and reformulating them in his own words.

Especially as he has been attacked for what he says and who he quotes, he is probably very careful about how he formulates his ideas.

Not to harp on a side point, but why not blaim the rabbanim for what is printed in their name? I could speculate about justifying their “Haggadot”, but ultimately, they have a veto power about what is printed by Artscroll in their name.

item.title: By: Michael Makovi
item.dc:creator: Michael Makovi
item.description:
Could you please explain the Artscroll gibberish ones? What exactly was the problem? Lack of quotation marks?
Maybe you could please post one representative quotation? If you don't want to reveal which book, what if you take that representative quote, change its references (if it used to say "The RambaN quotes Sanhedrin 55", change it to "The Rif quotes Nedarim 22", i.e. keep the structure but just completely changes all citations), and neglect to tell us its source. That way, we can see what you're talking about, but you won't reveal which book you're quoting.
item.content:encoded:
Could you please explain the Artscroll gibberish ones? What exactly was the problem? Lack of quotation marks?

Maybe you could please post one representative quotation? If you don’t want to reveal which book, what if you take that representative quote, change its references (if it used to say “The RambaN quotes Sanhedrin 55”, change it to “The Rif quotes Nedarim 22”, i.e. keep the structure but just completely changes all citations), and neglect to tell us its source. That way, we can see what you’re talking about, but you won’t reveal which book you’re quoting.

In reply to <a href="https://kavvanah.wordpress.com/2010/04/29/haggadot-2010/#comment-893">Jon Baker</a>.
Here is a full list including- Ephod Bad published in 1872 by Rabbi Benjamin David Rabinowitz Naftali Seva Ratzon by Rabbi Naftali Hertz Ginzburg 1708
http://www.oceansidejewishcenter.org/haggadot_translations_adaptions.html
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Jon Baker.

Here is a full list including-
Ephod Bad published in 1872 by Rabbi Benjamin David Rabinowitz
Naftali Seva Ratzon by Rabbi Naftali Hertz Ginzburg 1708

http://www.oceansidejewishcenter.org/haggadot_translations_adaptions.html
